02577 <HI>{@átha@}¦ ({@áthā,@} 248a), {%adv. expresses a sequence,%}
02578 {%temporal or resultant:%} then; so; so then;
02579 accordingly; thereupon; {@--1.@} {%temporal:%}
02580 {%e. g.%} {@áti drava, áthā…úpehi,@} run past, and
02581 then go unto…, 83^18^; {%in apodosis after%}
02582 {@yadā́,@} 84^5, 6, 7^, 96^22^; {@--2.@} {%resultant: e. g.%} {@ma-@}
02583 {@rúdbhiḥ sakhyáṃ te astu, átha jayāsi,@}
02584 make friends with the Maruts, and then
02585 (if thou dost) thou shalt conquer, 82^2^N.;
02586 {@--3.@} {%very frequent as a simple continuative:%}
02587 now; so; then; {%usually at beginning of sen-%}
02588 {%tence%} ({%e. g.%} 20^1^) {%or śloka%} ({%e. g.%} 2^6^); {%sometimes%}
02589 {%within the śloka%} ({%e. g.%} 3^14^); {%exceptionally at%}
02590 {%the end,%} 13^9^; {%at beginning of section or book,%}
02591 now, 98^16^; here beginneth ({%cf.%} {@íti@}), 1^1^;
02592 {%sometimes much attenuated in meaning; often%}

<L>993<pc>138-a<k1>ka<k2>ka/<h>1
04993 <HI>{@1ká@}¦ [504], {%pron.%} {@--1.@} {%interrogative.%} who,
04994 what; {%used as subst.%} (7^6, 7^) {%or as adj.%}
04995 (18^17^); {@kim@} {%w. instr.: e. g.%} {@kiṃ yuddhena,@}
04996 what (is there) with fighting, what's the
04997 use of fighting, 45^14^; {%so%} 17^19^, 24^9^; {%so%} {@ko@}
04998 {@‘rthas,@} 17^18^; {@kim@} {%w. instr. and gen.: e. g.%}
04999 {@nīrujaḥ kim auṣadhais,@} what has a well
05000 man (to do) with medicines, 22^3^; {%so%} 32^21^,
05001 51^20^; ka {%w. particles:%} {@ko nāma,@} who in-
05002 deed; {@ko nu,@} who pray; {@ko vā,@} who pos-
05003 sibly, 18^1^;
05004 <p>{@--2.@} {%indefinite, both adj. and subst., chiefly%}
05005 {%in negative clauses and w. the particles%} [{%see%}
[Page138-b+ 50]
05006 507] {@ca, caná, cid, ápi; --2a.@} {%w.%} {@mā́: mā́@}
05007 {@kásmai dhātam abhy àmitríṇe nas,@} de-
05008 liver us not over to any foe; {@--2b. ka ca,@}
05009 some, any, {%adj. or subst.;%} {@kiṃ ca,@} any-
05010 thing; {%w. relative,%} {@yāś (ca) kāś ca,@} (and)
05011 what soever, 68^10^; {@--2c.@} {%w.%} {@ca na@} {%and%}
05012 {@cana: ka ca na,@} also {%or%} even not any;
05013 {%esp. after a negative:%} {@na taṃ śaknuvanti@}
05014 {@vyāhartum api, kiṃ ca na,@} can not even
05015 speak to him, not even anything, {%i. e.%} can

05020 {%relative,%} soever; {@yat kiṃcana,@} whatsoever,
05021 9^16^; {@--2d.@} {%very often%} {@ka cid:@} any body {%or%}
05022 thing; certain, 18^11^; {%often w. negative: e. g.%}
05023 9^9^; 24^11^ ({%twice with, twice without%}); {@kiṃcit@}
05024 {@kiṃcid,@} each a little, 27^9^; {%w. relative,%} {@ya@}

05028 some, a {%or%} an, a certain, 21^2^; {@na ka api:@}

05030 <p>{@--3.@} {%derivs of%} {@ka,@} {%see%} 505; {@--4.@} {%exclam-%}
05031 {%atory, at beg. of cpds: cf., e. g.,%} {@kā-puruṣa,@}

<L>1169<pc>142-b<k1>kf<k2>kf<h>1
05442 <HI>{@√1kṛ@}¦ ({%Vedic,%} {@kṛṇóti, kṛṇuté@} [715]; {%later,%}
05443 {@karóti, kuruté@} [714]; {@cakā́ra, cakré;@} {%V.%}
05444 {@ákar, ákṛta@} [831, 834a]; {%later,%} {@ákārṣīt;@}
05445 {@kariṣyáti; kṛtá; kártum; kṛtvā́; -kṛ́tya;@}
05446 {@kriyáte; cíkīrṣati; kāráyati, -te@}). do,
05447 make, {%in the various meanings and uses of%}
05448 {%these words; thus,%}
05449 <p>{@--1.@} perform, 59^21^; accomplish; cause;
05450 effect; prepare, 83^15^; undertake, 52^2^;
05451 commit, 29^12^; show: {%e. g.%} honor, 5^6^; fami-
05452 liarity, 9^17^; compassion, 21^19^; love, 42^18^;
05453 favor, 52^21^; contempt, 54^16^; attend to:
05454 an affair, 11^4^; engage in: trade, 46^11^; a
05455 quarrel, 42^19^; {@--2.@} do something (good {%or%}
[Page143-a+ 50]
05456 bad) for a person ({%gen.%}), 3^2^, 9^15^; {@--3.@}
05457 make {%or%} procure for another, 82^4^; grant;
05458 {%--middle:%} get for one's self; assume:
05459 human voice, 3^14^; take on: form {%or%} shape,
05460 48^3^, 49^6^; {@--4.@} execute; follow: advice,
05461 40^7^; {@--5.@} work over, prepare: food, 68^3^;
05462 {@--6.@} accomplish; be good for, 18^5^; {@--7.@}
05463 make: a sound, 26^17^; utter: the syllable
05464 om, 60^8, 9^;</p>
05465 <p>{@--8.@} ({%like Eng.%} do {%in%} don, doff) put in
05466 {%or%} on; {%w. loc.,%} 81^1^, 43^6^; set, 105^14^; {%w.%}
05467 {%adverbs: see%} {@agratas, amā, āvis, tiras,@}
05468 {@puras, bahis;@} {@--9.@} make a person ({%acc.%})
05469 to be something ({%acc.%}), 79^12^; transform
05470 into, 40^13^ ff.; render, {%w. factitive predicate%}
05471 {%acc.,%} 18^8^; {%w. the predicate in composition%}
05472 [1094]: {%e. g.%} {@sajjī-kṛ,@} make ready, 34^17^;
05473 {@--10.@} {%w. adv. in%} {@-dhā,@} divide in parts,
05474 57^10^; {@--11.@} do, go to work, proceed, 37^8^;
05475 {%pass. impers.,%} 30^16^; {@--12.@} do, {%esp.%} sacred
05476 work; {%with%} {@karma,@} 97^2^; {%without%} {@karma@}
05477 ({%like%} <gr></gr> {%and%} facere), to sacrifice,
05478 93^12^; {%--see also%} {@kṛta.@}</p>
05479 <p>{%--desid.%} desire to perform; {%ppl.%} [1037],
05480 {@cikīrṣita,@} that which is sought to be done,
05481 intention.</p>
05482 <p>{%--caus.%} cause to do {%or%} make {%or%} be done
05483 {%or%} made; see to it that a thing takes
05484 place, 16^1^; {%pass.%} {@tena sa praṇāmaṃ@}
05485 {@kāritas,@} by him he was caused to make
05486 obeisance, 36^7^; {%caus. equiv. to simple verb,%}
05487 26^5^.</p>
05488 <p>[cf. <gr></gr>, ‘self-actor, indepen-
05489 dent’; <gr></gr>, an old harvest-god, ‘Per-
05490 ficus, the Completer, Ripener’; Lat. {%cer-us,%}
05491 ‘creator’; <gr></gr>, ‘accomplish’; Lat.
05492 {%creāre,%} ‘create’: {%see%} {@kratu:@} orig. root-
05493 form, perhaps, {@skṛ,@} 1087d.]</p>
05494 <HI>{@+ adhi,@}¦ put over; put in office.
05495 <HI>{@+ apa,@}¦ put off; injure, {%opp. of%} {@upakṛ.@}
05496 <HI>{@+ aram@}¦ {%or%} {@alam,@} {%see these words.%}
05497 <HI>{@+ ā,@}¦ bring hither, 74^10^; prepare, fashion,
05498 make.
05499 <HI>{@+ vy-ā,@}¦ separate, analyse.
05500 <HI>{@+ upa,@}¦ bring something to some one; do
05501 a service, act as an auxiliary, {%opp. of%}
05502 {@apakṛ.@} [w. the use of {@upa,@} cf. that of {%sub%}
05503 in {%subvenire,%} ‘aid.’]
05504 <HI>{@+ pari,@}¦ ({%poss.%} surround, deck, {%and so%})
05505 make ready; adorn.
[Page143-b+ 50]
05506 <HI>{@+ pra,@}¦ {@--1.@} carry forward, accomplish;
05507 effectuate, cause; {@--2.@} {%mid.%} set before;
05508 put before one, {%i. e.%} make the subject of
05509 discussion {%or%} treatment; {%w.%} {@buddhim,@} put
05510 a plan before one's self, {%i. e.%} decide.
05511 <HI>{@+ prati,@}¦ work against, counteract.
05512 <HI>{@+ sam,@}¦ {@--1.@} put together; conficere,
05513 prepare; {@--2.@} treat according to the
05514 sacred usages, administer a sacrament
05515 to, {%see%} {@saṃskāra;@} consecrate, 106^3^; {@--3.@}
05516 adorn.

<L>1448<pc>153-a<k1>ca<k2>ca
06492 <HI>{@ca,@}¦ {%encl. conj.%} and, also, <gr></gr>, que; {@--1a.@} {%is%}
06493 {%found, esp. in the older literature, with both%}
06494 {%parts to be connected%} ({%e. g.%} 71^5, 7^, 97^7, 11^; {%so%}
06495 13^5^, 16^12^, 17^3^, 19^10^, 38^7^, 9^2^); {%or only with%}
06496 {%the latter, as is oftenest the case in the later%}
06497 {%language%} ({%e. g.%} 2^1, 7^, 3^8^, 8^8^; 82^8^, 84^16^; 98^16^);
06498 {@--1b.@} {%in case of three or more parts to be%}
[Page153-b+ 50]
06499 {%connected,%} {@ca@} {%occurs: with the last only%} ({%e. g.%}
06500 {%three parts,%} 13^2^, 17^2^, 31^14^, 44^6^; 71^8^, 72^10^,
06501 83^15^; 106^5^; {%four parts,%} 2^2^, 17^7^, 28^10^; {%five%}
06502 {%parts,%} 2^5^, 21^5^, 25^3^); {%with the last two%} (7^6, 7^,
06503 22^5^, 37^15^, 45^7^; 77^12^); {%sometimes after each,%}
06504 (29^3, 4^); {%very rarely after the first of a scries%}
06505 (26^6^; 21^22^); {%various irregular combinations%}
06506 {%on page%} 67 {%passim; see also%} 21^20^N.;
06507 <p>{@--2.@} {%variously combined: w.%} {@eva@} ({%e. g.%}
06508 13^21^; 9^16^, 11^9^, 14^15^; 5^9^, 12^5^, 14^2, 8, 20^, 15^16^,
06509 25^4^; 30^14^), {%and w.%} {@api@} ({%see examples under%}
06510 {@api@});…{@ca,…tathā,…ca,@} both…, like-
06511 wise…, and, 10^8, 9^; {@…ca, …ā,@} both…,
06512 and…, 85^5^; {@sa ca,@} {%often at beg. of clause%}
06513 ({%e. g.%} 24^23^; {%so%} 34^18^; 41^7^); {@--3. anyac ca,@}
06514 {@api ca, kiṃ ca, tathā ca,@} {%joining two prov-%}
06515 {%erbs of like drift,%} moreover, further, like-
06516 wise;</p>
06517 <p>{@--4.@} {%otiose,%} 6^9^; {@--5.@} {%connecting things%}
06518 {%contrasted:%} but, 8^16^, 17^20^, 18^2, 3^, 19^2^; and
06519 yet, 1^12^, 3^20^; {@--6.@} (even, {%concessively, i. e.%})
06520 though, 26^12^; {@--7.@} ({%like Eng.%} and {%or%} an,
06521 {%and Icelandic%} enda, ‘moreover,’ ‘if’) if--
06522 {%see%} ced; {@--8.@} {%w. interrogatives, rendering%}
06523 {%them indef., see%} {@ka, kim.@}</p>
06524 <p>[cf. <gr></gr>, ‘and’; Lat. {%que,%} ‘and’; Goth. {%-h%}
06525 and Ger. {%-ch%} in {%ni-h%} and {%no-ch,%} the exact
06526 equivalents of Lat. {%ne-que,%} ‘and not, nor’:
06527 for {@ca@} 8, cf. <gr></gr> and <gr></gr> in <gr></gr> and Doric
06528 <gr></gr>, ‘at any time’; Lat. {%quis-que,%} ‘any,

<L>2138<pc>175-a<k1>Darma<k2>Da/rma
08656 <HI>{@dhárma,@}¦ {%m.%} {@--1.@} custom, 98^16^; usage,
08657 99^11^; right; duty, 28^6^; virtue, 21^7^, 10^13^,
08658 15^17^, 29^1^; (virtue, {%i. e.%}) good works, 29^5^,
08659 63^11^; correct course of conduct, 11^3^;
08660 {@dharme,@} in a question of right, 21^14^;
08661 {@--1a. dharmeṇa,@} {%adv.:%} as was right, 14^17^;
08662 dutifully, 16^5^; {@--2.@} law; prescription,
08663 rule; the law (as a system), 28^5^, 58^16, 19^;
08664 {@--3.@} {%personified,%} Virtue, 67^17^, 48^4^.
08665 <p>[a post-Vedic word, taking the place of
08666 V. {@dhárman: dharma@} is fr. {@√dhṛ@} (1166b),
08667 perhaps in mg 6, and thus designating
08668 ancient custom or right as ‘that which
08669 holds its own, which persists {%or%} endures’;
08670 but it may come fr. {@√dhṛ@} in mg 1, so that
08671 {@dharma@} is ‘that which is established {%or%}
08672 settled’; in the latter case, cf., for the
08673 mg, <gr></gr>, ‘that which is established as
08674 custom or law,’ w. <gr></gr>, ‘set, establish,’
08675 and Ger. {%Ge-setz,%} ‘law,’ w. {%setzen,%} ‘set.’]</p>

<L>2149<pc>175-b<k1>DA<k2>DA<h>1
08704 <HI>{@√1dhā@}¦ ({@dádhāti, dhatté@} [668]; {@dadhaú,@}
08705 {@dadhé; ádhāt, ádhita@} [884]; {@dhāsyáti,@}
08706 {@-te;@} {%V.%} {@-dhita,@} {%later%} {@hitá@} [954c]; {@dhā́tum;@}
08707 {@dhitvā́; -dhā́ya; dhīyáte; dídhiṣati,@}
08708 {@dhítsati; dhāpáyati@} [1042d]).
08709 <p>{@--1.@} put, 86^10^; set; lay, 39^14^; {@--2.@} put
08710 in a place, bring to, {%w.%} {@tatra,@} 85^19^; {%w. loc.,%}
08711 89^8^, 95^5^; {%w. dat.,%} 83^1^; {@--3.@} put upon, di-
08712 rect towards; {@dharme dhā manas,@} set the
08713 heart on virtue, 66^7^; {@--4.@} put something
08714 for a person {%(dat.), i. e.%} bestow upon him,
08715 grant him, 84^1^, RV. x. 125. 2; {@--5.@} put in
08716 a position, {%i. e.%} appoint, constitute, {%w. double%}
08717 {%acc.,%} 88^12^; {@--6.@} make, cause, produce;
08718 {@--7.@} hold, keep, 86^6, 9^; {@--8.@} {%mid.%} take to
08719 one's self, receive, obtain, win; {%esp.%} {@gar-@}
08720 {@bhaṃ dhā,@} conceive fruit in the womb,
08721 92^12^; {@--9.@} {%mid.%} assume, 19^7^; maintain;
08722 {@--10. hita,@} {%see s. v.;%} {@--11.@} {%desid. act.%} desire
08723 to grant; {%mid.%} desire to win.</p>
08724 <p>[The original meaning of the root is
08725 ‘put’; but, from the proethnic period, a
08726 secondary development in the line (‘set,’
08727 ‘establish,’ and so) ‘make,’ ‘do,’ is clear.
08728 The secondary mg has even won the more
08729 prominent place in Germanic and Slavic.</p>
08730 <p>For the primary mg, cf. <gr></gr>, ‘put’
08731 (the parallelism of its mgs is remarkable
08732 --<gr></gr>, ‘they set a stone’; <gr></gr>
08733 <gr></gr>, ‘conceive a son,’ etc., etc.); Lat. {%ab-%}
08734 {%de-re,%} ‘put off {%or%} away,’ and {%con-de-re,%} ‘put
08735 together, construct, establish’; Eng. do,
[Page176-a+ 50]
08736 ‘put,’ in the contract forms {%doff, don, dup;%}
08737 Ger. {%weg-thun,%} ‘do away {%or%} put away.’</p>
08738 <p>For the secondary mg, cf. <gr></gr>
08739 <gr></gr>, ‘make one a king’; AS. {%dōn hine%}
08740 {%tō cyninge,%} ‘make him a king’; Lat. {%fīo,%}
08741 ‘am made’; Eng. {%do, deed;%} Ger. {%thun,%}
08742 ‘do’; Slavic {%dĕ-lo,%} ‘deed’: observe that
08743 {%fi-eri,%} ‘become,’ is to {%fă-c-ere,%} ‘make,’ as
08744 {%ī-re (√ja),%} ‘go,’ is to {%jă-c-ere,%} ‘make to
08745 go, throw.’]</p>
08746 <HI>{@+ antar,@}¦ {@--1.@} put into the interior of
08747 a thing; {%and so%} {@--2.@} hide, conceal.
08748 <HI>{@+ api,@}¦ put close upon; cover (a jar with
08749 its lid); {@ápihita,@} closed up. [cf. <gr></gr>,
08750 ‘put upon.’]
08751 <HI>{@+ abhi,@}¦ put on; put a name upon, desig-
08752 nate; address; speak to, 43^10^; say, 42^20^;
08753 {@abhihitam,@} (it was) said, 38^13^.
08754 <HI>{@+ ava,@}¦ put down in; {%esp.%} duck ({%trans.%})
08755 into the water; {@ávahita,@} fallen into the
08756 water; {%caus.%} cause to be laid in.
08757 <HI>{@+ ā,@}¦ {@--1.@} put {%or%} lay {%or%} set in {%or%} on, {%w. loc.,%}
08758 77^1^, 79^12^, 88^15^, 90^5^, 102^21^; {@--2.@} put on
08759 (wood on the fire), 82^15^; {@--3.@} {%mid.%} set for
08760 one's self on (the hearth a sacred fire),
08761 95^12^; {@--4.@} {%mid.%} put on one's self, take on,
08762 74^6^; {@--5.@} take, {%i. e.%} take away, 87^10^.
08763 <HI>{@+ vy-ā,@}¦ {%pass.%} be separated; be uncom-
08764 fortable {%or%} sick.
08765 <HI>{@+ sam-ā,@}¦ put upon; {%w.%} {@manas,@} concen-
08766 trate the mind upon one thing; {@samāhita,@}

09020 <HI>{@ná,@}¦ {%adv.%} {@--1.@} not [1122b], 3^2^; {@--1a.@} {%in%}
09021 {%connected sentences or clauses: repeated%}

09023 63^13, 14^, 71^4^, {%ter;%} 4^13^, 17^18^, 74^1^, 80^17^, {%bis;%}

09025 {@na…, na ca…, na…,@} 63^1^; {%with%} {@api:@} {%see%}
09026 {@api@} 2; {%with%} {@u,@} 21^14^; {@--1b.@} {%not repeated,%}
09027 {%but replaced by%} {@api ca@} {%or%} {@vā_api@} ({%see these%}),
09028 2^12^, 63^4^; {@--1c.@} {%combinations:%} {@na ca,@} 8^16^;
09029 {@na…ca,@} 13^7^, 62^16^; {@naiva,@} 22^19^, 23^19^, 96^10^;
09030 {@na vai,@} 92^15^; {@na vā,@} 96^12^; {@na tu,@} 64^13^;
09031 {@na tv eva tu,@} {%see%} {@tu; na ha,@} 95^17^; {@na_iva,@}
09032 not exactly, 93^5^; {@--1d.@} {%tantamount to%} {@a-@}
09033 {%in negative cpds%} [1122b^4^], {%as%} {@nacira, nā-@}
[Page179-a+ 50]
09034 {@tidūra, nādhīta,@} etc.; {@--1e.@} {%at beg. of%}
09035 {%adversative clause: with adversative conj.,%}
09036 34^10^; {%without,%} 22^20^, 41^13^, 92^16^; {@--1f.@} {%in em-%}
09037 {%phatic litotes,%} 21^9^; {@--1g.@} {%substantive verb to%}

09040 {%immediately follows%} {@ced,@} {%it must be joined to%}
09041 {%the apodosis,%} 18^9^; {@--1i.@} {%for prohibitive nega-%}
09042 {%tive, see%} {@mā́; --1j. ná,@} ‘not,’ {%coalesces met-%}
09043 {%rically in Veda w. following initial vowel,%}
09044 {%e. g.%} 70^12^, 71^4^, 83^9^;

09046 {%Vedic only,%} 70^15, 18^, 71^7, 9^, etc.; {@ná,@} ‘like,’

09475 the three free castes as pupil, and at the
09476 same time invests him with the sacra-
09477 mental cord, thus conferring spiritual re-
09478 birth, and making him a full member of
09479 his caste; {%see%} {@upanāyana; upanīta,@} in-
09480 vested with the sacramental cord.
09481 <HI>{@+ pari,@}¦ lead around (a cow, steer), 91^14^,
09482 105^22^; {%esp.%} lead a bride around the fire
09483 (as wedding ceremony), {%page%} 99.
[Page183-b+ 50]
09484 <HI>{@+ pra,@}¦ {@--1.@} bring forward; {@--2.@} {%as litur-%}
09485 {%gical terminus technicus,%} convey the sacri-
09486 ficial fire and water to their places on and
09487 near the altar; {@praṇītās@} ({%sc.%} {@āpas@}), holy
09488 water; {@--3.@} bring forward (one's feelings),
09489 {%i. e.%} come out with {%or%} manifest one's affec-
09490 tion, 9^15^.
09491 <HI>{@+ vi,@}¦ lead; guide; train; discipline.

<L>2846<pc>198-b<k1>plu<k2>plu
11028 <HI>{@√plu@}¦ ({@plávate, -ti; puplā́va, pupluvé;@}
11029 {@áploṣṭa; ploṣyáti, -te; plutá; -plútya,@}
11030 {@-plū́ya@}). float through water {%or%} air:
[Page199-a+ 49]
11031 {@--1.@} swim; {@--2.@} bathe; {@--3.@} sail; {@--4.@}
11032 hover; fly; {@--5.@} fly off; hasten away;
11033 {@--6.@} spring; {@--pluta,@} floating, {%and so%} ({%see%}
11034 Whitney 78), protracted, of a vowel.
11035 <p>[cf. <gr></gr>, ‘float, sail’; Lat.
11036 {%pluere,%} ‘rain’: for mg of {%pluere,%} cf. the
11037 Eng. intrans. {%float,%} ‘swim,’ w. trans. {%float,%}
11038 ‘cover with water,’ and the intrans. {%bathe%}
11039 w. trans. {%bathe:%}</p>
11040 <p>closely connected w. {@√plu@} is the ex-
11041 tended form {@plud@} as seen in Lithuanian
11042 {%plud-iti,%} ‘swim, float’: w. this, cf. AS.
11043 {%fleōt-an,%} ‘swim {%or%} float about,’ Eng. verb
11044 {%fleet,%} ‘float, sail, hasten,’ Ger. {%fliessen,%}
11045 sometimes ‘swim,’ but usually ‘flow’;
11046 further, AS. {%fleōt,%} ‘raft, ship, fleet,’ Eng.
11047 {%fleet,%} ‘ships’; also AS. {%flota,%} ‘ship,’ Eng.
11048 {%float,%} ‘a thing that swims on the surface
11049 of a fluid, {%e. g.%} a raft’ (verb {%float%} is a
11050 denom. of this), Ger. {%Floss,%} ‘raft’; finally
11051 Eng. {%fleet,%} ‘streamlet {%or%} bay,’ whence {%The%}
11052 {%Fleet,%} as name of a small affluent of the
11053 Thames at London and of a famous prison
11054 thereon, and {%Fleet Street,%} which crossed
11055 The Fleet.]</p>

<L>2907<pc>201-a<k1>buD<k2>buD
11276 <HI>{@√budh@}¦ ({@bódhati, -te; búdhyate; bubódha,@}
11277 {@bubudhé; ábuddha@} [160]; {@bhotsyáti,@}
[Page201-b+ 50]
11278 {@-te; buddhá; bóddhum; buddhvā́;@}
11279 {@-búdhya@}). {@--1.@} be awake; {@--2.@} come to
11280 consciousness; {%hence%} {@--3.@} notice; give
11281 heed to, {%w. gen.,%} 76^12^; {@--4.@} notice, {%i. e.%}
11282 perceive; {%and so,%} become acquainted with;
11283 understand; {@--5.@} {%rarely,%} ({%like Eng.%} re-
11284 member a person, {%i. e.%}) presént a person
11285 with a thing {%(instr.); --caus.%} {@--6a.@} cause
11286 to notice {%or%} understand; {@--6b.@} teach;
11287 announce to.
11288 <p>[for {@*bhudh,@} orig. ‘be awake,’ cf.
11289 Church Slavonic {%bŭd-ĕti,%} ‘be awake’: the
11290 cognate words of the related lauguages
11291 agree closely in form, but show consider-
11292 able diversity of mgs: mg 4 mediates
11293 the transition to the idea of the Greek
11294 <gr></gr>, in <gr></gr>, ‘find out’: mgs 5
11295 and 6 form the bridge to the principal
11296 Germanic mgs, ‘offer’ and ‘command’:
11297 cf. Goth. {%ana-biud-an,%} (prob. ‘give notice
11298 to,’ and so) ‘command,’ AS. {%beōd-an,%}
11299 ‘announce, offer, command,’ Eng. {%bid,%}
11300 ‘announce, offer in words, offer {%in general,%}
11301 {%esp.%} at an auction, declare, proclaim, com-
11302 mand, invite,’ Ger. {%biet-en,%} ‘offer’; (from
11303 an entirely different root is Eng. {%bid,%} AS.
11304 {%biddan,%} Ger. {%bitten,%} ‘pray,’ as in {%bid beads,%}
11305 ‘pray prayers’;) cf. also Eng. noun {%bode,%}
11306 ‘announcement,’ whence denom. verb
11307 {%bode,%} ‘foretell’: for mg 5, observe the
11308 analogy of Ger. {%Jemand bedenken,%} ‘re-
11309 member {%or%} take notice of a person {%esp.%} in
11310 one's will, {%i. e.%} make a bequest to.’]</p>

11312 7^9^.

11314 sciousness; awake, {%intrans.%}

<L>2950<pc>203-b<k1>Baj<k2>Baj
11514 <HI>{@√bhaj@}¦ ({@bhájati, -te; babhā́ja, bhejé@} [794e];

11516 {@bhaktá; bháktum; bhaktvā́; -bhájya;@}
11517 {%caus.%} {@bhājáyati@}). {@--1.@} deal out; appor-
11518 tion; divide; {%then%} ({%as Eng.%} share {%means%}
11519 {%both%} ‘give a part of’ {%and%} ‘have a part of’)
11520 {@--2.@} {%middle,%} have as one's part, receive;
11521 have {%or%} take part in; {@--3.@} give one's self
11522 up to; {@--4.@} (choose as one's part, {%i. e.%}) de-
11523 clare one's self for, prefer, 15^3^; {@--5.@} be-
11524 take one's self to; turn to; go to, 20^10^;
11525 {@--6.@} belong to, be attached to; revere;

11526 love, 9^20^; {%--caus.%} cause to have a share,
11527 {%w acc. of person and gen. of thing,%} 83^8^.
11528 <p>[cf. <gr></gr>, ‘get one's portion, eat,’
11529 w. a specialization of mg like those seen
11530 in Eng. {%partake%} and {%take%} as used with the
11531 implied object {%food%} or {%drink,%} in {@bhakta,@}
11532 ‘thing divided, portion, food,’ and in
11533 {@bhakṣ:@} akin are the names of the two
11534 food-trees yielding eatable nuts (acorns,
11535 buck-mast), <gr></gr>, ‘oak,’ Lat. {%fāgus,%}
11536 ‘beech,’ AS. {%bōc,%} Eng. {%buck-,%} ‘beech-,’ in
11537 {%buck-mast,%} ‘beech-nuts,’ and {%buck-wheat%} (so
11538 called from the likeness of the kernels to
11539 beech-nuts), AS. {%bēce,%} Eng. {%beech:%} with {%bōc,%}
11540 ‘beech,’ is ident. {%bōc,%} ‘book,’ orig. ‘runes
11541 scratched on branches of a fruit-bearing
11542 tree,’ see Tacitus, Germania, x.; such a
11543 branch was called by a name which became
11544 in Old High Ger. {%puah-stap%} or {%buoh-stab,%}
11545 and meant orig. ‘beech-staff’; but the
11546 word came to be used for the significant
11547 thing on the branch, ‘the rune {%or%} letter,’
11548 AS {%bōc-stæf,%} Ger. {%Buch-stabe.%}]</p>
11549 <HI>{@+ ā,@}¦ {%act., sometimes mid.,%} deal out to, give
11550 a person ({%acc.%}) a share in a thing ({%loc.%}).
11551 <HI>{@+ vi,@}¦ part asunder; divide.

13122 {@mṛditvā́; -mṛ́dya@}). press {%or%} rub hard,

13125 </gr>, ‘destroy’ e. g. a wall: w. {@mṛdú,@} ‘soft,
13126 weak,’ cf. Lat. {%mollis, *molvis, *moldv-i-s,%}
13127 ‘soft, weak,’ and <gr></gr>, ‘slow’

13129 {%weak,%} and Lat. {%lēn-is,%} ‘soft,’ w. {%len-tus,%}
13130 ‘slow’):</p>

13132 of the snow,’ we might compare <gr></gr>,
13133 ‘melt,’ Eng. {%melt;%} but the {%s%} of the col-
13134 lateral form {%smelt%} makes this doubtful:

<L>3364<pc>220-b<k1>ya<k2>ya/
13218 <HI>{@yá@}¦ [509], {%relative pron.%} {@--1.@} who, which;
13219 {%sometimes following its correlative:%} 7^6^, 17^18^,
13220 29^5^, 30^15^, 33^16^, 52^7^, 73^9^, 78^10^, 79^7^;
13221 {@evambhūto vidvān, yas…samarthas,@}
[Page221-a+ 50]
13222 tam doctus…qui possit, 19^4^; {@--2.@} {%but%}
13223 {%much oftener preceding its correlative:%} {@ya@}
13224 {@…ta,@} 77^12^, 69^7^, 3^13^, 17^13^, 21^23^, 22^4^, 30^11^,
13225 32^10^; {@yā́ni…eṣām,@} 74^3^; {@yac ca_ucyate@}
13226 {@…, etad ālasyavacanam,@} and (what is
13227 said, {%i. e.%}) as for the saying…, that is
13228 [fatalists’] sloth-talk, 18^8, 11^;
13229 <p>{@--3.@} {%converting the subject or object of a%}
13230 {%verb into a substantive clause:--sometimes,%}
13231 {%perhaps, merely for metre:%} 29^3^, 38^7^, 58^6^;
13232 {%but often for emphasis:%} 9^18^, 56^19^, 57^7^; {@yé@}
13233 {@pakṣā́ ā́saṃs, té jīmū́tā abhavan,@} what
13234 were wings, those became clouds, {%for%} {@té@}
13235 {@pakṣā́ abhavan jīmū́tās,@} 93^3^; {@ayáṃ yó@}
13236 {@hótā, kír u sá yamásya,@} who this priest
13237 [is], is he also that of Yama, 88^10^; {%so%}
13238 {@yad,@} {%even w. words of different gender and%}
13239 {%number, as,%} {@prajā́pater vā́ etáj jyeṣṭháṃ@}
13240 {@tokáṃ, yát párvatās,@} of P. that [was] the
13241 first creation, what the mountains are,
13242 92^19^; {%so%} 95^15^, 97^1^;</p>
13243 <p>{@--4.@} which, what, {%as adj. pron. agreeing%}
13244 {%w. incorporated antecedent:%} {@ná_asmai vid-@}
13245 {@yút siṣedha, ná yā́m míham ákirad@}
13246 {@dhrādúniṃ ca,@} not for him did the light-
13247 ning avail, not what mist he scattered
13248 abroad, and hail, 71^4^; {%so%} 71^20^ {%to%} 72^2^, 74^4^,
13249 79^9^ ?, 83^3^, 88^7^; {%as subst. pron., the ante-%}
13250 {%cedent not being expressed,%} 74^1, 2^, 78^18^;</p>
13251 <p>{@--5.@} {@ya@} {%in special connections:%} {@ya ya@}
13252 [511], whoever, whichever, whatever, who-
13253 soever, etc., 13^12^, 45^13^; {%so%} {@ya ka ca,@} 68^10^;
13254 {@ya ka cid,@} 60^22^, 68^12^; {@ya ka cana,@} 9^16^;
13255 {@ya ka cid,@} anyone soever, no matter who,
13256 quīlibet, 21^11^; {%so%} {@ya ta,@} 18^4^; {@--6.@} {%two or%}
13257 {%more relatives in the same clause:%} {@yo 'tti@}
13258 {@yasya yadā māṃsam,@} when (who) some-
13259 one eats the flesh of (whom) someone,
13260 29^7^; {%so%} 37^11^, 66^18^; {@--7.@} {@ya,@} if anybody,
13261 si quis ({%really an anacoluthon%}): {%so%} 79^16^;
13262 {@--8.@} {@ya, and…he,@} 74^15^; {@--9.@} {%for further%}
13263 {%illustration, see%} 512, 511; {%for derivatives,%}
13264 510; {%for influence on the accent of the verb,%}
13265 595; {%cf.%} {@yad, yasmāt, yāt, yena.@}</p>
13266 <p>[orig. and primarily a demonstrative
13267 (like Eng. {%that%} and Ger. {%der%}): cf. <gr></gr>, ‘he,’
13268 in <gr></gr>, ‘said he’; <gr></gr>, ‘so,’ in <gr></gr>,
13269 ‘not even só’; --secondarily a relative
13270 (like Eng. {%that%} and Ger. {%der%}): cf. <gr></gr> or
13271 <gr></gr> for <gr></gr>, ‘who, which’; hence {@yā́t,@}
[Page221-b+ 50]
13272 with which cf. <gr></gr>, ‘as’; --but these com-
13273 parisons are rejected in toto by some.]</p>

<L>3486<pc>227-b<k1>raj<k2>raj
13892 <HI>{@√raj@}¦ {%or%} {@rañj@} ({@rájyati, -te; raktá; -rájya;@}
13893 {%caus.%} {@rañjáyati@}). {@--1.@} be colored; {%esp.%}
13894 be red; {@rakta:@} red; dyed; {%as n.%} blood;
13895 {@--2.@} {%fig.%} be affected with a strong feeling
13896 ({%cf.%} {@raj + vi@}); {%esp.%} be delighted with,
13897 have pleasure in, be in love with; {%--caus.%}
13898 {@--1.@} color; redden; {@--2.@} delight, please,
13899 make happy.
13900 <p>[orig. ‘be bright {%or%} white’ (whence
13901 {@rajaka@}); then ‘glow, be red’: see the
13902 ident. {@√3ṛj@} and its cognates <gr></gr>, etc.;
13903 and cf. <gr></gr> in aor. <gr></gr>, ‘dye,’ and
13904 <gr></gr>, ‘dyer’: w. this root may be con-
13905 nected the root {@rāj@} in its mgs given
13906 under 2.]</p>
13907 <HI>{@+ anu,@}¦ {@--1.@} be colored after, take the
13908 tinge of; {@--2.@} feel affection towards.
13909 <HI>{@+ vi,@}¦ {@--1.@} lose color; {@--2.@} be cold {%or%}
13910 indifferent towards ({%loc.%}), 45^3^. [for mg
13911 2, cf. the senses of the simple verb: the
13912 metaphor may be either ‘not glowing,’
13913 and so, as in Eng., ‘cold,’ or else ‘color-
13914 less,’ and so, ‘indifferent.’]

<L>3488<pc>227-b<k1>rajas<k2>ra/jas
13918 <HI>{@rájas,@}¦ {%n.%} {@--1.@} atmosphere, air, region of
13919 clouds, vapors, and gloom, clearly dis-
13920 tinguished from heaven ({@dyaus,@} 72^2^) or
[Page228-a+ 50]
13921 the ethereal spaces of heaven ({@rocanā@}
13922 {@divas,@} 81^8^, or {@svar@}), “where the light
13923 dwelleth,” these being beyond the {@rajas,@}
13924 just as the <gr></gr> is beyond the <gr></gr>;
13925 {%used loosely in pl.,%} the skies, 71^7^; the
13926 sky conceived as divided into an upper
13927 and a lower stratum, {%and so dual,%} {@rajasī,@}
13928 75^5, 12^; {%so far Vedic;%}
13929 <p>{@--2.@} {%post-Vedic: like the Greek%} <gr></gr>, the
13930 thick air, mist, gloom, darkness; {@--3.@}
13931 dust, {%e. g.%} 14^13^; {@--4.@} {%in the philosophical%}
13932 {%system,%} darkness ({%cf.%} 2), the second of the
13933 three qualities ({%see%} {@guṇa@}), soul-darkening
13934 passion (popularly connected with {@rāga,@}
13935 ‘passion’), 66^8, 16^.</p>
13936 <p>[since the orig. mg, as indicated by
13937 usage, is ‘the cloudy (region), region of
13938 gloom and dark’ as distinguished from
13939 the everlasting light beyond, the word is
13940 prob. to be derived fr. {@√raj@} in the sense
13941 ‘be (colored, {%i. e.%}) not clear’: cognate are
13942 <gr></gr>, ‘darkness, Erebus,’ and Goth.
13943 {%riqis,%} neut., ‘darkness’: for connection of
13944 mgs 2 and 3, cf. Ger. {%Dunst,%} ‘vapor,’ and
13945 Eng. {%dust.%}]</p>

15194 groom's house, wed; {@--6.@} carry, 43^11, 16^,
15195 52^9^; bear, 26^4^; carry far and wide, {%i. e.%}
15196 spread (a poem, fragrance), 54^2^.

15198 <gr></gr>, ‘ride’; Lat. {%veh-ere,%} ‘carry’; {%vehi-%}
15199 {%culum,%} ‘wagon’; AS. {%weg-an,%} ‘carry, bear,’

15201 {%anchor%}), ‘find weight of by lifting’ (cf.
15202 {@bhara@}); AS. {%wægn%} or {%wæ1n,%} Eng. {%wain,%}

15204 {%wagon%}), ‘that which is drawn, {%i. e.%} wagon’;

<L>3845<pc>243-b<k1>vid<k2>vid<h>1
15508 <HI>{@√1vid@}¦ ({@vétti; véda@} [790a]; {@ávedīt;@}
15509 {@vediṣyáti, -te; vetsyáti, -te; viditá;@}
15510 {@véditum, véttum; viditvā́; -vídya; ve-@}
15511 {@dáyati@}). {@--1.@} know; understand; per-
15512 ceive; ya evaṃ veda, who knoweth thus,
15513 who hath this knowledge, {%frequent formula%}
15514 {%in the Brāhmanas,%} 97^3^; {@vidyāt,@} one should
15515 know, it should be known {%or%} understood;
15516 {@--2.@} recognize as; {@nalam māṃ viddhi,@}
[Page244-a+ 50]
15517 recognize me as N., know that I am N.;
15518 {@--3.@} notice; be mindful of, 75^13^; bethink
15519 one's self, 94^6, 10^; {@--4.@} believe; assume;
15520 consider a person ({%acc.%}) to be…({%acc.%}),
15521 43^19^; {%--ppl.%} {@vidvā́ṃs,@} {%see s. v.%}
15522 <p>[with {@véda, vidmá,@} cf. <gr></gr>, AS.
15523 {%ic wāt, wē witon,%} ‘I know, we know’; Eng.
15524 {%I wot,%} gerund {%to wit,%} noun {%wit,%} ‘under-
15525 standing’: cf. also <gr></gr>, ‘saw’;
15526 Lat. {%vidēre,%} ‘see’; AS. {%wītan,%} ‘see’;
15527 whence {%wīt-ga,%} ‘seer, soothsayer, wizard’
15528 (Icelandie {%vit-ki,%} ‘wizard’), {%wicca,%} ‘wizard,’
15529 {%wicce,%} ‘witch,’ Eng. {%witch,%} masc. and fem.:
15530 {@véda@} is an old preterito-present, ‘have
15531 seen {%or%} perceived,’ and so, ‘know’--see
15532 {@√2vid:@} the forms of the other tense-
15533 systems are comparatively modern.]</p>
15534 <HI>{@+ anu,@}¦ know along, {%i. e.%} from one end to
15535 the other, know thoroughly.
15536 <HI>{@+ ni,@}¦ {%caus.%} cause to know; do to wit;
15537 announce; communicate.
<LEND>

<L>3970<pc>248-b<k1>vI<k2>vI<h>1

15984 seek eagerly; {@--2.@} accept gladly; enjoy;
15985 {@--3.@} strive to get; {@--4.@} fall upon.
15986 <p>[cf. Lat. {%vēnāri,%} ‘hunt,’ a denom. of
15987 {%*vē-na,%} ‘hunt’; AS. {%wā-<gr></gr>,%} ‘hunt’; Old
15988 High Ger. {%weida,%} ‘1. the seeking, {%esp.%} of
15989 food, {%i. e.%} hunting, fishing, {%and then%} 2. place
15990 for getting food, pasture, {%and%} 3. food,
15991 fodder’; {%weida%} appears w. mg 1 in Ger.
15992 {%Waid-mann,%} ‘hunter’ (also as family
15993 name, {%Weidmann,%} ‘Hunter’), and w. mgs
15994 2 and 3 in {%Weide,%} ‘pasture, food’: per-
15995 haps {@2váyas,@} ‘food,’ q. v., comes fr. {@√vī@}
15996 in mg 1, ‘seek for, hunt,’ and in this case
15997 the development of mg is like that of
15998 {%weida%} 3 and like that of Lat. {%vēnātiōn-em,%}
15999 ‘hunting, game,’ whence Eng. {%venison.%}]

16128 exclude, separate.</p>

16130 {%or%} position, by bending {%or%} diverting {%or%}

16176 ‘twist,’ whence come: Eng. {%writhe;%} AS.
16177 {%wræ1<gr></gr>,%} ‘a twisted band,’ Eng. {%wreath; wrist,%}
16178 earlier {%hand-wrist, *-wri<gr></gr>-st,%} ‘hand-turner’:</p>

16180 whence {%versāre,%} ‘turn much’: for mgs
16181 3-6 of {@vṛt,@} cf. Lat. {%versāri,%} whose senses
16182 are quite parallel, and the Eng. phrase
16183 “in whom we live and {%move%} and have our
16184 being.”]</p>

<L>4523<pc>270-a<k1>sah<k2>sah
18151 <HI>{@√sah@}¦ ({@sáhate; sasā́ha, sasahé; ásahiṣṭa;@}
18152 {@sahiṣyáte; soḍhá@} [222^3^]; {@sáhitum, só-@}
18153 {@ḍhum; -sáhya@}). {@--1.@} overpower, 99^8^;
18154 be victorious, 78^4^; {@--2.@} hold out against,
18155 withstand; {%and so%} bear; endure patiently,
18156 32^7^.
18157 <p>[orig. ‘be powerful, withstand, hold
18158 back, hold’: cf. the collateral {@√sagh,@}
18159 ‘take on one's self, bear’: cf. <gr>-
18160 </gr>, ‘hold back’; <gr></gr>, ‘hold {%or%}
[Page270-b+ 50]
18161 have, had’: --w. {@sahas, *sagh-as,@} cf. the
18162 Germanic stem {%seg-oz,%} as it appears in
18163 Goth. neut. {%sigis,%} AS. {%sigor,%} prob. neuter,
18164 all meaning ‘victory’; the stem appears
18165 also in {%Seges-tes,%} name of a Cheruscan
18166 prince (Tacitus, Annals), and in {%Sigis-%}
18167 {%mund:%} cf. also AS. {%sige,%} Ger. {%Sieg,%}
18168 ‘victory.’]
18169 <HI>{@+ ud,@}¦ {@--1.@} hold out, endure; {@--2.@} be
18170 able, {%w. inf.;%} {@kathaṃ svārtham utsahe,@}
18171 how can I ({%sc.%} do, prosecute) my own

18408 <HI>{@síndhu,@}¦ {@--1.@} {%in V., m.%} stream; {@--2.@} {%in V.%}
18409 {%and later, f.%} The Stream, {%i. e.%} the Indus
18410 (incolis Sindus appellatus--Pliny); {@--3.@}
[Page273-a+ 50]
18411 the land on the Indus and its inhabitants
18412 ({%pl.%}). [cf. the Old Persian form {%hindu%}
18413 (in an inscription of Darius Hystaspis at
18414 Persepolis), as name of the land on the
18415 Indus: hence, w. loss of aspiration, the
18416 classical form <gr></gr>; hence also Persian
18417 {%Hind,%} ‘India,’ and {%Hind-u-stan%} ({%stan%} =
18418 {@sthāna,@} ‘abode, land’).]

19431 Swayamvara.

<L>4934<pc>288-a<k1>hotf<k2>ho/tf
19930 <HI>{@hótṛ,@}¦ {%m.%} {@--1.@} priest, chief priest, whose
19931 assistant in oldest times was the {@adhvar-@}
19932 {@yu;@} Agni, as the chiefest {@hotṛ,@} 69^2^, 88^6^;
19933 {@--2.@} {%in the highly developed ritual,%} the first
19934 of the four chief priests, {%see%} {@ṛtvij.@} [prop.
19935 ‘offerer,’ from {@√hu,@} ‘offer’: but the sense
19936 of ‘invoker,’ naturally suggested by his
19937 function in the ritual, was popularly asso-
19938 ciated with it and the word thus connected
19939 with {@√hū,@} ‘invoke.’]
